comments:
CIS 520 provides a fundamental introduction to the mathematics, algorithms and practice of machine learning. Covering the foundations of statistical machining, this course focuses on probabilistic and statistical methods for prediction and clustering in high dimensions. This course is generally aimed at upper level undergraduates and graduate students. The software used in the course is MATLAB. All required readings are distributed in class, and there are a number of optional texts such as Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning by Christopher Bishop.

For the most part, students enjoyed the course and reported learning “a ton of useful information.” Students generally “liked the course a lot” and found its content to be “very good.” While there were some students who found the course to be “sub-par,” the general feeling was positive, and some even reported that it was “one of the top courses [they] have taken” at Penn.

Professor Taskar was highly regarded by most of the students in the class. Many found him to be “a great guy who is easy to relate to” and “awesome.” While many students reported that Professor Taskar “clearly taught…a lot of new material,” others suggested that he should take more “time to cover the material thoroughly and slowly…rather than rush” through the material. 

The majority of students in the course were advanced undergraduates or graduate students. For the most part, students felt that the course required a “truck-load of work,” and they agreed that the project was “extremely time consuming.” Some students reported that the course would be much better if the amount of coursework was lightened.
